awd_titl_txt: Stochastic Constitutive Laws in Nonlinear Mechanics: Application to the Multiscale Modeling of Arterial Walls for Robust Vascular Grafting
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, the use of computational stochastic analysis is put forward in order to construct a new modeling and computational framework for nonlinear stochastic constitutive laws. Modeling the uncertainties in the constitutive behavior of nonlinear materials is a central challenge in computational mechanics and mechanics of materials. In particular, the large variability exhibited by soft biological tissues, such as vascular vessels, is a current roadblock to computational assisted surgeries, patient-specific treatments for cardiovascular diseases and wide adoption of tissue engineering approaches. In this project, the use of computational stochastic analysis is put forward in order to construct a new modeling and computational framework for nonlinear stochastic constitutive laws. The specific case of vascular constructs is purposely chosen as a prototypical application combining strong anisotropy and a high level of stochasticity. The research supported by this award will enhance the predictive capabilities of simulations involving biological materials, such as arterial and brain tissues, and will be relevant to a large class of materials, including the case of damaged composites. The interdisciplinary standpoint promoted in this effort will enable a broad exposure to students involved in various fields, such as applied mathematics and materials science, and will allow theoretical and computational aspects to be introduced through outreach activities in local high schools.
 
This research is focused on computational stochastic analysis for nonlinear constitutive laws. More specifically, it aims at deriving probabilistic models, a high-performance-computing environment for sampling on smooth manifolds and methodologies for the identification and validation of spatially dependent anisotropic strain energy functions. By addressing the proper mathematical randomization of nonlinear constitutive equations in close relation with calibration and validation concerns, the research supported by this award will notably advance a new information-theoretic class of stochastic methods where randomness can be accounted for from potentially multiscale experiments to coarse-scale simulations. The project will involve a set of methodological and theoretical developments, including (1) the construction of physics-based random field models and sampling algorithms for a class of polyconvex stored energy functions, and (2) the definition of methodologies for the data-poor inverse calibration and multiscale validation of the stochastic models. The novel framework will notably be used within large-scale nonlinear simulations to investigate the probability of failure of stochastic vascular constructs with patient-specific geometries.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the probabilistic modeling of hyperelastic materials, with a particular emphasis on the passive mechanical response of arteries. The nonlinear behavior of such biological tissues can be theoretically described by a strain energy function and exhibits large variability due to a variety of physiological factors such as age, gender, and health condition. This intrinsic, nonreducible variability can have a dramatic impact on clinical diagnosis and surgical procedures.

A methodology to extend existing, validated models to a probabilistic setting was proposed. The approach aims to ensure both phenomenological consistency and well-posedness for subsequent computational and mathematical analysis. The framework relies on information theory and the principle of maximum entropy, which is invoked to derive least-informative prior models. Using this method, we derived first-of-their-kind stochastic models for strain energy functions, considering the case of anisotropic and isotropic, homogeneous and heterogeneous materials. We have shown that these models can reproduce experimental results on human arteries very well, for both uni- and bi-axial testing. We also developed a formulation that allows for the heterogeneous models (where stochastic material parameters are allowed to vary spatially) to be sampled from on very complex, patient-specific geometries obtained by magnetic resonance imaging. The method combines a stochastic partial differential equation that implicitly defines a latent Gaussian field, pushed forward by the aforementioned information-theoretic model, with auxiliary Laplace problems that enable the definition of natural correlation paths on the fly. This computational framework can be used, in particular, as a generative model for the mechanical response of nonlinear composites. These simulations can also be used to locate spots of likely failure along the arterial wall and can therefore inform procedures in a virtual testing paradigm.

Other activities completed in this project include (1) the application of the proposed framework to other problems involving complex geometries, such as buckling analysis and topology optimization, and engineered composites; and (2) the development of admissible data-driven constitutive models for anisotropic hyperelastic materials. These findings were published in a series of papers in top-ranked journals and in two book chapters, and were widely disseminated through conference communications in the US and abroad. Finally, closed integration of research outcomes in teaching material was pursued at the undergraduate and graduate levels. Graduate students supported by this award received highly competitive awards at the national and international levels.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2021
Modified by: Johann Guilleminot
